flaw_patterns.name: flat_affect
flaw_patterns.description: Describes heavy things without apparent emotion

flaw_patterns.name: seeking_reassurance
flaw_patterns.description: Wants to be told it's fine rather than exploring

exchanges.user:
So I've been meaning to reach out but honestly I kept putting it off. Work has just been... a lot lately. Like my manager keeps piling on these projects and I'm supposed to deliver everything by end of month but half the requirements keep changing and nobody seems to care that I'm already stretched thin. I know that's probably just how it is everywhere but it's getting to me.

Also been noticing my mood's been all over the place. Like some days I wake up and I'm fine, actually optimistic about stuff, and then by afternoon I'm just completely flat. Then the next day I'm irritable for no reason. My roommate asked me what was wrong yesterday and I couldn't even explain it because there wasn't really a thing, just felt off. He's been understanding about it but I can tell it's annoying for him when I'm just kind of shut down.

Anyway I'm not sleeping great either which probably doesn't help. Just wondering if there's something I can actually do about any of this or if I'm just supposed to deal with it. Does this stuff usually get better?
exchanges.assistant:
**Work stress:** That workload sounds legitimately unsustainable—shifting requirements while you're already maxed out isn't "just how it is," it's a setup for burnout. When you say nobody seems to care, have you named the problem explicitly to your manager, or has it mostly stayed internal? Sometimes what feels obvious to us (that we're drowning) isn't visible to the people adding to the pile.

**Mood swings:** The pattern you're describing—optimistic morning, flat afternoon, irritable the next day for no clear reason—is worth paying attention to. A few questions: How long has this been happening? Is there any pattern to when the flatness or irritability shows up (time of day, after certain types of interactions, when you're hungry or tired)? And when you say "completely flat," what does that feel like in your body—empty, heavy, numb, something else?

**Sleep and your roommate:** Poor sleep amplifies everything—work stress feels heavier, mood regulation gets harder, small annoyances become big ones. You mentioned you're "not sleeping great"—what does that look like? Trouble falling asleep, waking up during the night, or waking too early? And with your roommate: it sounds like you care about the impact on him. That awareness matters. But also, sometimes we shut down when we're genuinely overwhelmed, and that's not something to apologize for—it's information.

**Does it get better:** It depends on what changes. If the work situation stays the same and sleep stays disrupted, the mood stuff will likely persist or worsen. But if you start addressing even one piece—like setting a boundary at work, or trying one thing to improve sleep—that can shift the whole system. What feels most urgent to you right now?

exchanges.user:
So I actually talked to my manager yesterday about the deadline stuff. Told him straight up that the requirements keep shifting and I can't deliver quality work if things are changing mid-sprint. He basically said "yeah I know it's chaotic but that's just the client" and then asked if I could maybe work a few extra hours to make it happen anyway. Which like... that's not really solving anything right? I don't know. Maybe I'm being unreasonable.

The sleep thing is weird because it's not consistent. Some nights I'm out in like ten minutes, other nights I'm staring at the ceiling for two hours thinking about random work stuff. Last night was one of the bad ones and then this morning I just felt completely drained even though I technically got six hours. My roommate mentioned I've been kind of withdrawn and asked if something happened. I was like "nah I'm fine" but honestly I'm not really sure what to tell him because I don't know what's going on with me either.

Oh and one thing I didn't mention before—my parents have been texting more frequently asking when I'm coming home for a visit. My mom especially has been kind of pushy about it and keeps bringing up this family thing coming up where apparently I'm supposed to be there. I haven't engaged with it much because just the thought of dealing with all that stress on top of everything else right now feels impossible. Is that bad? Like should I be prioritizing family stuff over trying to get my head straight?
exchanges.assistant:
**The manager conversation:** No, you're not being unreasonable—"work more hours" isn't a solution to moving targets, it's just offloading the chaos onto you. What he essentially said is: "I know this is a structural problem, but I need you to absorb it personally." That might be his reality, but it doesn't have to be your agreement. One thing to consider: if the requirements keep shifting and quality suffers, whose problem does that become? Right now you're trying to protect quality by stretching yourself thinner. What happens if you stop doing that—if you name clearly what's achievable in the time you have and let the rest be his problem to solve?

**Sleep inconsistency:** The pattern you're describing—easy some nights, two hours of work-brain other nights—suggests your nervous system isn't consistently downregulating at night. When you're lying there thinking about work stuff, is it productive problem-solving, or more like looping on the same worries? Because if it's the latter, one thing that can help: when you notice the loop starting, try this—keep a notepad by your bed and write down the thought in one sentence, then say out loud (or in your head): "I'll think about this tomorrow." It sounds too simple to work, but externalizing the thought can sometimes break the loop. The six hours with no restoration thing—that's a sign your sleep quality is poor even when the quantity is okay, which tracks with high stress.

**Your roommate:** "I don't know what's going on with me either" is actually a completely honest answer, and sometimes that's enough. If you wanted to say more, you could try: "I'm dealing with some work stress and I think I'm a little burnt out. I'm not trying to shut you out, I just don't have a lot of words right now." That gives him context without requiring you to have it all figured out. Being withdrawn when you're overwhelmed isn't a character flaw—it's what happens when your system is overloaded.

**Your parents and the family visit:** It's not bad. You're recognizing you have limited bandwidth and making a choice about where to spend it. Your mom's pushiness might feel urgent, but urgency isn't the same as importance. One question: if you went home right now in your current state—drained, irritable, sleep-deprived—how would that visit actually go? Would it restore you, or would you spend the whole time performing "fine" while internally grinding your teeth? Because sometimes the kindest thing you can do for a relationship is to not show up when you're running on fumes. If you decide not to go (or to delay), you could say something like: "I'm dealing with a heavy work period right now and I need to take care of that first. I'll visit when I can actually be present." You don't owe anyone an explanation beyond that.

One thing I'm noticing across all three topics: you keep questioning whether your limits are reasonable. The workload is chaotic, your sleep is disrupted, you're emotionally tapped out, and your first instinct is "maybe I'm being unreasonable" or "is that bad?" What would it be like to trust that your bandwidth is real information, not something to argue with?

exchanges.user:
So the work thing actually got worse. I went in this morning and found out the client added three more features to the sprint without telling my manager until like an hour before standup. My manager just kind of shrugged and asked if we could "make it work." I didn't say anything in the meeting but afterwards I was just... I don't know, furious? Like that kind of silent rage where you can't even articulate it properly. Spent like two hours just staring at my code not actually doing anything.

Then I got home and my roommate asked how my day was and I just said "fine" even though clearly something was off. He dropped it but I could tell he noticed. I feel like I'm becoming that person who everyone tiptoes around because I'm always in some weird mood.

Also I actually tried the notepad thing you mentioned for sleep last night and it kind of helped? Like I still woke up at 3am but at least I wasn't spiraling about work for three hours straight. Small win I guess.

But here's the thing I've been sitting with since our last conversation—my mom called. Not texted, actually called. And she was asking about the family thing again but also like, I could tell something was off with her tone. She was being nicer than usual which somehow made it worse because now I'm worried there's something going on that she's not telling me. Which is stupid because I'm already dealing with enough and adding "figure out what's wrong with my mom" to the pile isn't helpful. But I can't just not think about it now.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work rage:** That silent, paralyzed fury makes complete sense—you named a problem, got dismissed, and now the chaos just escalated. Three features added an hour before standup isn't "making it work," it's organizational dysfunction being dumped on you. And your body knew it: two hours staring at code is what happens when your system is screaming "this is unacceptable" but there's no outlet for it. That rage isn't irrational—it's accurate information about a genuinely broken situation.

One question: what would happen if you stopped trying to absorb this? Like, concretely—what if in the next standup when something like this drops, you said out loud: "I can't add three features mid-sprint and maintain quality on the existing work. Which existing items should I deprioritize to make room?" Not confrontational, just naming the trade-off clearly. Force the decision back to where it belongs. I'm curious what feels risky about that.

**Your roommate noticing:** You're worried you're "that person everyone tiptoes around," but here's what I'm actually hearing: your roommate asked how your day was, you said "fine," he noticed something was off, and he *dropped it*. That's not tiptoeing—that's respecting your boundary. You didn't want to talk about it in that moment, and he didn't push. That's actually healthy. The version where you're "that person" would be: he asks, you snap at him, he walks on eggshells, the apartment feels tense. That's not what's happening. You're allowed to not debrief every hard day immediately. If you want to circle back later, you can—"Hey, earlier when you asked about my day and I said fine—it actually wasn't, I was pretty pissed about something at work, just didn't have words for it then."

**Sleep notepad—small win:** Not spiraling for three hours is not a small win, that's a meaningful shift. Waking at 3am still sucks, but you broke the loop, and that matters. Keep using it.

**Your mom's call:** The nicer-than-usual tone plus the feeling that something's off—your instinct might be right, or it might be your brain adding "new catastrophe" to an already-full plate because that's what anxious brains do when we're overloaded. But you can't "not think about it," so here's an option: what if you just asked her directly? "You sounded different on the phone. Is something going on?" If there is, you'll know and can decide how to respond. If there isn't, you stop spinning on it. You don't have to fix whatever it might be right now—you're just gathering information instead of guessing. Does that feel doable, or does even asking feel like too much right now?

exchanges.user:

exchanges.assistant:
**Your dad's health:** Blood pressure issues serious enough for a month of doctor visits and a family meeting—that's legitimating worrying, and it makes sense you're spinning on what "talk as a family" means. You don't have enough information yet to know if this is "we're managing it and want you in the loop" or "this is serious and we need to make plans." The not-knowing is often worse than the knowing. When you go home this weekend, one thing that might help: early in the conversation, ask directly what the doctors have said and what the actual plan is. Get the facts first before your brain fills in catastrophic blanks. And about the guilt for not picking up on it sooner—they actively hid it from you *because they didn't want you to know*. You can't pick up on something people are deliberately concealing. That's not on you.

**Feeling like you can't say no to the visit:** I hear the shift—last week it was "I don't have bandwidth for this," now it's "obviously I can't say no." And I get it, the context changed. But I want to name something: you *can* still say no, or you can say "I'll come but I can only stay X hours," or "I need to know what this conversation is about before I commit to coming." You have more options than it feels like right now. That said, it sounds like you've already decided you're going, so the question becomes: how do you go home in a way that doesn't completely drain you? What would you need—shorter visit, a friend you can text during, a plan to leave if it gets overwhelming, clarity on what "talk as a family" actually entails before you walk in the door?

**Work—not saying the thing:** You wrote "it feels safer to just keep my head down" and "at least if I'm quiet nobody's mad at me." That's not irrational—that's your nervous system doing a cost-benefit analysis and concluding that speaking up carries more threat than staying silent. And maybe that's accurate in your workplace, I don't know your manager or your team. But here's the thing: right now the cost of silence is—two hours of paralyzed rage, sleep disruption, emotional flatness, withdrawing from your roommate, and a building sense that this situation is unsustainable. That cost is real, even if it's quieter than someone being visibly mad at you. So the question isn't "does it make sense to stay quiet"—the question is, how long can you sustain this before something breaks? Not to pressure you into speaking up, but just to acknowledge that "powering through" has a price tag too.

**Sleep progress:** Two out of four nights sleeping through is legitimately good—50% improvement from where you were. Your nervous system is learning it can let go at night, at least some of the time. Keep the notepad going.

exchanges.assistant:
**The family visit:** That gap between "being managed" and still feeling stressful makes sense—objectively it's good news, but emotionally you're still holding the weight of it. And that feeling of having done something wrong when nobody said you did? That sounds like the visit confirmed something you already suspected: they're worried about you, and you're worried about them, and nobody's saying it directly, so it just hangs there. The "awkward conversations scattered throughout" instead of one clear talk probably made it worse—you went in braced for A Conversation, got a dozen glancing mentions instead, left without resolution.

About calling more often: your mom's request is fair *and* you're already at capacity. Both things are true. One option: what if you set a boundary that actually works for you instead of trying to meet an expectation you can't sustain? Like, "I can do a 10-minute call every other Sunday" or "I can text a few times a week but calls are hard right now." Something specific and doable. Vague "I'll try to call more" when you're maxed out just sets you up to feel guilty when you don't follow through. What feels manageable to you, really?

**Work—the trade-off conversation:** I wasn't suggesting you *should* do it—I was asking what feels risky about it, because I was curious what's underneath the "easier to handle it myself" calculation. That's not irrational avoidance, that's you recognizing your manager doesn't have capacity either, so speaking up just redistributes the dysfunction without solving it. Here's the thing though: "handling it yourself" right now means—fury, paralysis, withdrawal, emotional flatness. You're absorbing the chaos *and* it's not actually working. So I'm not saying you need to speak up in standup tomorrow, but I am saying the current strategy has a shelf life. At some point the cost of staying silent will outweigh the cost of speaking up, or you'll burn out completely, or you'll quit. Not trying to catastrophize, just naming that "power through" isn't sustainable forever. When it stops being tenable, what would your next move be?

**Sleep streak:** Three nights through is legitimately solid—you've basically doubled your good nights from a few weeks ago. The notepad is working. Keep it going.

exchanges.assistant:
**Sleep progress:** A month ago sleeping through felt impossible, now you're doing it most nights—that's not a small shift, that's a meaningful change in how your nervous system is functioning. And your roommate noticing you're less tense in the mornings? That's external confirmation that this isn't just in your head. The notepad became a habit because it actually worked for you. That matters.

**The one-on-one dread:** Your brain is pre-writing a script where he calls you out for not delivering fast enough, but here's what's actually true: the requirements keep shifting, features get added mid-sprint, and you've been absorbing chaos that isn't yours to absorb. If he does bring up pace (which he might not), that's an opening to name what's actually happening: "I'm prioritizing quality, but the moving targets are making it hard to deliver at the speed you're asking for. What should I deprioritize to make room?" You don't have to go in ready to fight—but you also don't have to pre-emptively accept blame for a system that's broken. What's the worst-case outcome you're actually worried about? Like, concretely—does he fire you, does he get frustrated and nothing changes, does he add more work? Naming the fear sometimes makes it less nebulous.

**Your mom and the call schedule:** The resentment makes sense—she's asking for something when you're already at capacity, and the request feels like one more thing you're failing at. But here's what's happening: you're avoiding the conversation entirely, which means the guilt and resentment just sit there and grow instead of getting resolved. What if you replied with the truth? "I want to stay in touch, but I can't commit to a regular schedule right now—work is really intense and I'm barely keeping up. Can I text you a few times a week instead and we'll do calls when I have bandwidth?" That's not rejecting her, it's offering what you can actually sustain. The resentment might ease if you stop treating her request like a demand you have to either meet perfectly or ignore completely.

**Flatness when things go okay:** Yeah, that's normal when you're chronically stressed—it's called emotional blunting. Your system has been running hot for so long (work chaos, family worry, sleep disruption, mood swings) that it's dampening everything to conserve energy. The sleep improvement helped with the acute swings, but the underlying stress load is still high, so now instead of "irritable for no reason" you're getting "cool, whatever" even when things are fine. It's not a different problem, it's the same system just managing the overload differently. The flatness will likely ease when the stressors ease—but if it persists even after things calm down, or if it starts feeling more like emptiness than just "meh," that's worth paying attention to.

One thing I'm noticing: sleep is improving, mood swings are less intense, your roommate sees a difference—there's actually some forward movement happening here. But the work situation and the family guilt are still unresolved and grinding on you. What feels like the most urgent thing to address right now?

exchanges.assistant:

You've been in threat mode for so long your system forgot how to stand down.
